feed.title: Why Satoshi's temporary anti-spam measure isn't temporary

entry.title: Why Satoshi's temporary anti-spam measure isn't temporary
entry.summary: Bitcoin initially had no block size limit, with the belief that a fee market would develop and create economic constraints on growth. However, an influx of new users led to the implementation of a temporary anti-spam measure: a one megabyte block size limit. While this was meant to be a test with the intention to increase it later, a fee market never developed, and validation costs were externalized to the entire network. Additionally, miners didn't properly validate blocks, and thin clients lacked a secure mechanism to obtain short proofs for their transactions. As a result, the block size debate remains a contentious issue in the Bitcoin community.
